statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Creighton 71, Akron 60
article.story: OMAHA, Neb. (AP) -- If Creighton was still disappointed over not getting an NCAA tournament bid, the Bluejays didn't show it against Akron in their first-round NIT game. Pierce Hibma hit consecutive 3-pointers to open the game and the Bluejays quickly built a double-digit lead they held most of the night in a 71-60 victory over the Zips on Thursday. Afterward, coach Dana Altman and his players talked about how they have come to embrace their appearance in the NIT, their consolation prize after losing four of their last six games. "We came out fired up," said Anthony Tolliver, who led the Bluejays with 18 points. "It's an opportunity to play. That's what we wanted. It's not in the context we wanted. We wanted to be in the NCAA, obviously. It's an opportunity keep playing ball." Creighton (20-9) showed no adverse effects from having 13 days off since their loss to Bradley in the first round of the Missouri Valley Conference tournament. The Bluejays led 40-26 at halftime. "The guys played with some energy tonight," Altman said. "We got a few shots down, which helped us get going. This time of year, when you don't play for 13 days, that's really a long time." The Bluejays will host Miami in a second-round game Monday. A meeting with Michigan or Notre Dame awaits the winner. Altman said if his team continues to advance in the NIT, it would help the MVC counter the knocks against the conference, which had four teams earn NCAA bids. "There is no way we're going to get Miami to come in here on a home-and-home, so it's a good opportunity for us," Altman said. "You've got to get excited about having the chance of going to Michigan or having Notre Dame come in here. You can't look ahead, but having those teams in the bracket and having those opportunities we just don't get." The chance to play those 'name' opponents cushions the blow of not making the NCAA, Altman said. "We're disappointed we're not in the NCAA tournament, knowing that one or two games was the difference. That really makes you disappointed," Altman said. "But our program will never be at the point where we can look our noses down at the NIT." Akron (23-10) finished with its most wins since the school started playing Division I basketball in 1980-81. While Creighton had to wait almost two weeks between games, the Zips had one day to prepare for Creighton after winning 80-73 in overtime at Temple on Tuesday. "I thought we were a half-step slow," Akron coach Keith Dambrot said. "I thought two of our best players, Cedrick Middleton and Dru Joyce, just didn't really have it. I know I was extremely tired yesterday. I felt like I had been run over by a truck. I can only imagine what it was like for the players." Nick Porter had 15 points, Hibma 14 and Johnny Mathies 11 for the Bluejays. Romeo Travis had 25 points to lead the Zips, who shot just 35.5 percent and were outrebounded 43-34. Nick Dials was 3-for-6 on 3s and finished with 11 points. Middleton had six points and Joyce was held scoreless. Hibma, who was 3-for-16 from long range in his last seven games, made all of his career-high four 3-pointers in the first half. Akron got within 18-15 on a Darryl Peterson basket, but Tolliver hit a 3 to start a 9-0 run that put the Bluejays up 27-15. The win gave the Bluejays 20 victories for an MVC-record eighth straight season. "That was one of our goals coming into the season, and it was good to get that accomplished to keep the tradition alive here," Dane Watts said. "Nobody on the team wanted to be part of the team that broke that streak, so we're glad to get that off our back. Now everybody is focused on getting number 21."
